Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Aspects of Integrating Heterogeneous and Inconsistent Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Integrating heterogeneous data is a major challenge that manifests itself across a wide spectrum, from government and business to science and health care. A critical task underlying this challenge is deriving the relationship between different database schemas. During the past decade, schema mappings have emerged as the right tool for this task. Schema mappings are high-level, declarative specifications of the relationships between two database schemas that provide the appropriate level of abstraction and, at the same time, can be compiled into executable code.

The first main aim of this project is to develop a framework and tools for designing schema mappings. This framework is based on the systematic use of data examples. The project investigates fundamental algorithmic tasks in using data examples as a device to illustrate and understand the behavior of already derived schema mappings, and also as inputs to a schema-mapping design system that will derive a suitable schema mapping based on the given data examples. The second main aim is to investigate the uses of schema mappings in integrating and exchanging inconsistent data that arise when bringing together data from heterogeneous sources. Since the current framework of data exchange does not handle inconsistencies well, this project re-examines data exchange and extends it to gracefully handle inconsistencies.

This project will advance the state of the art in designing schema mappings and managing inconsistent databases. Furthermore, it will contribute to the development of human resources in science and engineering through the teaching and research training of graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Integrating heterogeneous data from different sources is a major current challenge that manifests itself across a wide spectrum, from government and business to science and health care. This challenge encompasses a collection of inter-related problems that include extracting and cleaning data from the sources, deriving a unified format for the integrated data, transforming and materializing data from the sources into data conforming to the unified format, and answering queries over the unified format. A critical task underlying these problems is the derivation of schema mappings, which are syntactic constraints that specify the semantic relationship between different database schemas.

The main aim of this project was to advance the state of the art in the design of schema mappings and to investigate their uses in integrating and exchanging inconsistent data.  The intellectual merit of this project is that it produced a number of results in two different, but related, areas. The first was the development of a framework, tools, and a prototype system for schema-mapping derivation based on data examples. The second was the development of a framework that extends data exchange and allows for the graceful handling of inconsistencies.  New algorithms were designed, implemented, and evaluated in the course of this project. A total of 31 publications resulted from this project. These consist of 22 publications in peer-reviewed computer science conferences and 9 publications in archival computer science journals. One of the conference publications was recognized with the Best Paper Award at the 2015 International Conference on Database Theory, while the full versions of several other conference publications were subsequently invited to special issues of journals.

The broader impact of this project was the development of human resources in science and engineering through the teaching, mentoring, and research training of graduate students. Two graduate students at the University of California Santa Cruz are currently completing their doctoral dissertations on topics investigated during this project.  Moreover, the PI and the coPI undertook extensive dissemination activities, including invited talks, tutorials at computer science conferences, and short courses in advanced schools for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers
